↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Can't believe I've somehow not been using tmux for the last couple of years. Bloody useful! Especially when going between computers. ssh in, tmux attach, and there's the whole session.

@eldersnake@yarn.andrewjvpowell.com It‚Äôs brilliant along with mosh if you ever are in a position of shotty connectivity

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic the compiler you have installed is unaffected. The compiler that's downloaded functions as a library that your installed build system and interpreter use to compile other code.

As @lyse@lyse.isobeef.org pointed out, this is a bit of a security nightmare. Now you have a compiler that will download another version of the compiler (you hope) ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Happy birthday Nanook! 1 year already :) Media

@stigatle@twtxt.net You probably answered this before, but what breed of dog is Nanook? ü§î

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @abucci I get there are situations where this might be helpful, but all the security implications etc. No thanks! It's already kind of bad with dependencies, but the toolchain itself is a whole different level. I've set all the variables already in advance.

@lyse@lyse.isobeef.org I really wish Russell Cox and co would seriously reconsider what they are doing with the language and toolchain. They seriously risk affecting the reputation of Go here in ways that cannot be predicted (just look at history for some examples). I can seriously see a Go fork coming out of this.

Maybe it is because I am running yarn.social through a compose/stack configuration? Perhaps I should set it up as a container directly.

@carsten@yarn.zn80.net What does it show when it doesn‚Äôt start?

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª can I post on yarn through curl?

And finally to make a post:

curl -s -d '{"text": "Hello World!"}' -H "Token: $YARND_TOKEN" http://localhost:8000/api/v1/post | jq '.'

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª can I post on yarn through curl?

To verify the API endpoint(s) are working (no authentication required):

curl -s http://localhost:8000/api/v1/ping

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª can I post on yarn through curl?

To verify that you are logged in and authenticated:

curl -s -d '' -H "Token: $YARND_TOKEN" http://localhost:8000/api/v1/whoami

can I post on yarn through curl?

curl -s -d '' -H "Token: $YARND_TOKEN" http://localhost:8000/api/v1/whoami

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª can I post on yarn through curl?

To securely login and authenticate to the API and set YARND_TOKEN env var for later use:

IFS= read -rsp 'Password: ' password; payload="$(jq -cnr --arg password "$password" '{username: "admin", "password": $password}')"; export YARND_TOKEN="$(curl -s -d "$payload" http://localhost:8000/api/v1/auth | jq -r '.token')"
content.value:

can I post on yarn through curl?

To securely login and authenticate to the API and set YARND_TOKEN env var for later use:
IFS= read -rsp 'Password: ' password; payload="$(jq -cnr --arg password "$password" '{username: "admin", "password": $password}')"; export YARND_TOKEN="$(curl -s -d "$payload" http://localhost:8000/api/v1/auth | jq -r '.token')"

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª The /metrics endpoint is there for the operator, so you can monitor/measure your pod's performance and adjust accordingly, or file bug reports for me to fix broken shit‚Ñ¢ ü§£ -- It is never pushed anywhere, only pulled. And I only ever pull two key pieces out dao and mao of known single and multi-user pods, but I ASK beforehand ü§£ -- For example I'm not pulling DAU and MAO stats from @kaniyama_t 's Twitter2 pod because I never got a response to whether I could or not üòÖ

Although performance metrics that measure CPU, Memory and such aren‚Äôt really the same thing as ‚Äútelemetry‚Äù
